thread.title: EasyJet boosted by fly and flop market
thread.title_full: EasyJet boosted by fly and flop market

title: EasyJet boosted by fly and flop market
text:
Save 
Demand for beach destinations across Europe has helped easyJet to a better-than-expected performance in its third quarter. 
Although revenue was down 1% to £1.2 billion the results were better than the guidance the company issued in May. 
Trading in the UK and demand for sunny destinations helped offset the impact of a shift in Easter and the French air traffic control strikes in April. 
Carolyn McCall, easyJet Chief Executive said: “Our Q3 performance shows that easyJet’s strategy continues to deliver, in particular with good performance in the UK and beach routes across Europe. 
“With 77% of second half seats now booked, easyJet expects to grow profit before tax from £581 million for the year to 30 September 2014 to a range of £620 million to £660 million for the year to 30 September 2015. 
“Our Q3 performance means that for the full year easyJet will grow revenue, profits and dividends.”
